Expectation1: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation1: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: At a communal event, the catered dishes lack certification and substituting food would be difficult.
Story:
I stood at the bench, the weight of my robe heavy on my shoulders, as I read the jury instructions aloud. My mind was focused, every word measured, when my clerk slipped me a note—urgent, trembling. The Supreme Court had just overturned the very precedent I was explaining. My heart pounded. I was expected, as a judge, to stay current, to uphold the law as it stands, not as it was. I paused, the courtroom silent, all eyes on me, waiting for my next move.

Later, at the courthouse’s communal dinner, I scanned the buffet. None of the dishes bore kosher certification. My colleagues urged me to join in, plates already full, laughter echoing. I felt the familiar ache of exclusion, the expectation to participate, to be part of the team. But my faith demanded I refrain, even if it meant going hungry. The demands of my roles pressed in from all sides—one requiring immediate adaptation, the other steadfast adherence. I stood, torn, the weight of both worlds pressing down, uncertain which expectation I could bear to disappoint.
